en_first_half: The judge and the widow went to law to get the court to take me away from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it was a new judge that had just come, and he didn’t know
en_second_half: the old man; so he said courts mustn’t interfere and separate families if they could help it; said he’d druther not take a child away from its father. So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to quit on the business.
en_results: the old judge's ways, so he said he would have to hear the case for himself, and would call on both of us in the morning. I was glad, for I didn't want to go back to the widow's any more, and I reckoned I could get
en_results_raw: the old judge's ways, so he said he would have to hear the case for himself, and would call on both of us in the morning. I was glad, for I didn't want to go back to the widow's any more, and I reckoned I could get the judge to let me off easy. But I was mistaken; for the first thing the judge did in the morning was to send for the widow, and then he told me to take off my coat and come up and be sworn. I took the oath, and then the judge begun to ask me questions, and he made me tell the whole story out. I told him everything, just the same as I have told it to you, and when I got done he called the widow in and asked her about it. She told the same story, only she said I was a bad boy and had run away from her many times, and that I had been very ungrateful and disobedient. The judge thought for a while, and then he says to me, "I believe you, Huck, and I believe you have been treated very badly, but I am going to let you off this time, and I am going to make the widow your guardian, but I want you to promise me that you will be a good boy and go to school and learn your lessons, and not run away from the widow any more." I promised, and the judge said I could go.

Jim se tumbó en la canoa y se cubrió con la colcha, y yo comencé a remar con todas mis fuerzas, intentando alejarme lo más posible de la isla. El sol estaba alto en el cielo y el mar estaba en calma, lo que me permitió remar con mayor facilidad. A medida que nos alejabamos de la isla, pude ver a los centinelas patrullando por la orilla, pero no parecían haberse dado cuenta de nuestra fuga. Seguí remando durante horas, hasta que el sol comenzó a ponerse en el horizonte. Entonces, me detuve un momento para descansar y mirar hacia atrás, y pude ver la isla a lo lejos, con los centinelas todavía patrullando por la orilla. We bailed it out with our hands, and then we found the oars and set to work to get away from the wreck as fast as we could. It was a big relief to be in the boat and clear of the wreck, but it was a mighty solemn feeling too, you can bet, to be afloat on the big river, with nothing to make us go, and no place to make for, and nobody in sight to help. We looked at each other, and I reckon we both thought the same thought—that we was in a pretty tight fix, and we didn't see no way out of it that was very bright. Then I got to thinking over our troubles, and I says to myself: "Well, if a body can get ashore on a place where you are so handy to a town, and yet can't make a living there, it's a mighty poor sort of business." And then I says to myself: "If a body can't do better than this on the main highway of America, with all these towns and cities lined up along the river, and nothing to do but go from one to another and pick up a job here and there, and have plenty to eat and drink, and get paid for it, and get on the steamboat and ride from town to town, and see all the sights, and have all the adventures a body could want, and go home when he gets ready, with a pocket full of money and a heart full of joy, why, it's a mighty poor sort of business, that's all." And then I says to myself: "I'll just take a notion, and see if I can't strike something better than this." So I took a notion, and I struck out for the island. I says to Jim: "I'm going to take a swim, and see if I can't find some berries or something." Jim says: "I'm going to set here and rest, and maybe I'll take a nap." I says: "Suit yourself, Jim, but I'm going to find something to eat, or I'll know the reason why." So I struck out, and I swum ashore, and I found some berries, and I eat them, and they was good, and I felt better, and I went back to the boat, and Jim was asleep, and I didn't disturb him, and I set down and took a nap myself. When I woke up, Jim was awake, and we set to work to bail out the boat, and we got her emptied, and then we set to work to make a sail, and we made one out of Jim's shirt, and we set it on a pole, and it blew a pretty good breeze, and we went a- sailing, and we sailed all day, and we made a good many miles, and we was getting along pretty well, when we spied a steamboat coming, and we knowed it was the "Diana", and we was glad, and we sailed towards her, and we hailed her, and she answered, and we went aboard, and we was safe, and we was sound, and we was happy, and we was free. And that's the story of how me and Jim run away from the Duke and the King, and went to the island, and struck it rich, and got away, and got aboard the "Diana", and went to Cairo, and got a job, and got paid, and got rich, and lived happy ever after.

And then you'd see the river had risen, and the current was stronger, and you'd have to be careful not to get too close to the shore, or you'd get caught in an eddy and have to pull like the mischief to get out again. And then you'd see some more rafts, and some logs, and maybe some brush, and you'd know the river was rising, and you'd have to be careful not to get caught in a sawyer, or you'd be in a fix. And then you'd see some birds flying around, and you'd know they were after something, and you'd look and see some fish swimming around, and you'd think about how you'd like to have a line in the water, and be catching some of them. And then you'd hear some more thunder, and see some more lightning, and you'd know the storm wasn't over yet, and you'd be glad when it was all over and the sun came out again.

El secretario asintió con la cabeza, sonriendo también, y juntos se dispusieron a examinar aquellas ropas con más detenimiento, descubriendo en ellas secretos y detalles que les hablaban de la vida cotidiana de la corte medieval.

en_first_half: There was a little one-horse town about three mile down the bend, and after dinner the duke said he had ciphered out his idea about how to run in daylight without it being dangersome for Jim; so he allowed he would go
en_second_half: down to the town and fix that thing. The king allowed he would go, too, and see if he couldn’t strike something. We was out of coffee, so Jim said I better go along with them in the canoe and get some.
en_results: down to the town and back in the night, and show us the ropes. I was a good deal afraid, but Jim said the duke's plan was good, and we'd better do it, because there warn't no other way for us to get out
en_results_raw: down to the town and back in the night, and show us the ropes. I was a good deal afraid, but Jim said the duke's plan was good, and we'd better do it, because there warn't no other way for us to get out of that scrape. So we waited till it got dark, and then the duke slipped down to the town, and in about an hour and a half he come back, and says: "It's all right, we can do it, and I've fixed it so we can't get caught." He says: "We'll start at the lower end of the town, and work right up it, and take all the houses that's got white or light-colored clothes hanging on the line; and do it as quick as we can, and not make no noise, and get away as fast as we can." He says: "The first light-colored clothes we see, we'll take 'em, and then go on and take the next, and the next, and so on, till we get to the upper end, and then we'll make a dash for the woods, and hide, and then we'll be safe."

Y al fin, después de mucho cavilar, se me ocurrió una idea. ¡Era una idea genial! Me fui a ver al notario y le expliqué la situación.
